A non-contrast CT of the brain shows no acute abnormalities. Due to his symptoms, the physician orders an MRI to assess for subtle brain injuries. What type of MRI image is shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI)

 

The MRI image shown is Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI), a type of gradient echo sequence that is highly sensitive to magnetic susceptibility effects caused by substances such as blood, iron, and calcium.

 

Key Features 

 

Sensitivity to Magnetic Susceptibility: SWI detects compounds that distort the local magnetic field, such as deoxygenated blood, hemosiderin, and iron. This makes it particularly useful for identifying microhemorrhages, venous malformations, and calcifications.

 

  1. Characteristic Appearance: SWI shows dark (black) dots representing areas of hemorrhage or iron deposition, often referred to as "blooming artifacts." This makes it the ideal sequence for identifying subtle bleeding, especially in cases of diffuse axonal injury.
  2. Clinical Use: SWI is the sequence of choice for evaluating traumatic brain injury (TBI), particularly for detecting diffuse axonal injury (DAI) where small hemorrhages occur due to shearing forces. It is also used to assess other conditions like cerebral microbleeds, cavernomas, and venous anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1-weighted image: T1-weighted sequences are primarily used for anatomical detail and do not show the susceptibility effects seen in SWI.

 

Option B. T2-weighted image: T2-weighted sequences highlight fluid and edema but do not have the sensitivity to magnetic susceptibility that SWI provides.

 

Option C. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI): DWI is used to detect areas of restricted diffusion, such as in acute stroke, but it does not highlight magnetic susceptibility effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) is a specialized MRI sequence used to detect substances that alter magnetic susceptibility, such as blood products and iron. It is particularly useful in diagnosing conditions like diffuse axonal injury and microbleeds due to its ability to visualize small areas of hemorrhage that are not detectable on other MRI sequences.

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding by spoon


Feeding with a spoon is a social milestone that typically develops around 18 months of age. If a child is unable to feed themselves with a spoon by 24 months, it can be considered a developmental delay. By the age of 3 years, most children should have well-established self-feeding skills, including the ability to hold and use a spoon effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one leg: This milestone typically develops around 4 years of age. It would not be considered a delay if a 3-year-old is unable to hop on one leg.

 

Option B. Drawing a square: Drawing a square is a fine motor skill that generally develops around 4 and a half years of age, so its absence at 3 years old is not considered a delay.

 

Option D. Passing a ball to someone: This social and motor skill usually develops around 4 years of age. Therefore, a 3-year-old not being able to pass a ball would not be considered delayed.

 

Educational Objective:


The absence of feeding with a spoon by 24 months can indicate a developmental delay in social and motor skills in a child.

choices.text: Cell mediated and antibody mediated response

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cell mediated response

 

A Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T cells that provoke an inflammatory reaction against exogenous or endogenous antigens. In certain situations, other cells, such as monocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils, can be involved. After antigen exposure, an initial local immune and inflammatory response occurs that attracts leukocytes. The antigen engulfed by the macrophages and monocytes is presented to T cells, which then becomes sensitized and activated. These cells then release cytokines and chemokines, which can cause tissue damage and may result in illnesses. It is considered a delayed hypersensitivity reaction because it usually occurs more than 12 hours after exposure to the allergen, with a maximal reaction time between 48 and 72 hours.

 

Examples of illnesses resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell mediated and antibody mediated response: This is not correct for Type IV hypersensitivity, which is exclusively cell-mediated and does not involve antibodies.

 

Option C. Antibody mediated response: This describes Type I, II, and III hypersensitivities, which involve IgE, IgG, or IgM antibodies, respectively. Type IV is exclusively cell-mediated.

 

Option D. Innate response: While the innate immune response involves cells like macrophages and neutrophils, Type IV hypersensitivity specifically involves the adaptive immune system, particularly T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated response primarily involving T cells and other immune cells, leading to delayed-type reactions such as contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

The four types of hypersensitivity are:

 

  1. Type I: reaction mediated by IgE antibodies
  2. Type II: cytotoxic reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies
  3. Type III: reaction mediated by immune complexes
  4. Type IV: delayed reaction mediated by cellular response

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

This statement is incorrect because it is the female mite, not the male, that burrows into the skin. The male mites mainly stay on the surface of the skin and do not create burrows like the females do.

 

The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

 

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

 

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months. 

 

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life history has 4 stages: The lifecycle of Sarcoptes scabiei consists of the egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages, correctly described in the statement.

 

Option B. Larvae have 3 pairs of legs: The larvae of the scabies mite indeed have three pairs of legs, distinguishing them from the adult mites.

 

Option C. The entire life cycle takes about 15 days: The lifecycle from egg to mature mite, under ideal conditions, typically spans around 15 days, making this statement accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. CECT done reveals a Stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta blocker medication

 

Beta-blockers are used to control the heart rate and blood pressure in patients with aortic dissection. This helps in reducing the sheer force exerted on the wall of the aorta, which may help in preventing the progression of the dissection. Beta-blockers are the first-line medication for heart rate and blood pressure control in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin): This is an anticoagulant used to prevent or treat blood clots. In the context of an aortic dissection, it's not the initial management as it might increase the risk of bleeding within the dissection.

 

Option C. Surgical repair: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A (DeBakey type I and II) ascending aortic dissection. However, before surgery, it is crucial to stabilize the patient's vital signs, and beta-blockers play a significant role in this aspect.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibitors: These are anticoagulants that act by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Like LMWH, they are not the initial management for aortic dissection due to the potential risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is Beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The Preferred Beta-blocker drug is Esmolol.

 

Once hypertension is controlled, then definitive repair of aortic dissection is done based on Stanford type.

 

Stanford Classification:

 

  • Type A: This type involves the ascending aorta and possibly the descending aorta. It is considered the more dangerous type and often requires emergency surgery. Given its involvement with the ascending aorta, it's critical to manage promptly to avoid complications such as rupture or impairment of blood flow to vital organs.
  • Type B: Involves only the descending aorta.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe, sudden, tearing chest pain
  • Pain that radiates to the back/scapula
  • Shortness of breath
  • Sweating
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body (in rare cases)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Medications, especially beta-blockers, are often given initially to lower heart rate and blood pressure, reducing the force of blood against the aortic walls and potentially preventing further tearing.
  • Surgical Intervention: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A dissections. The surgery aims to repair the damaged section of the aorta and to prevent rupture or further dissection. Endovascular repair is preferred for Stanford B.

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. Walter Reed showed that yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.
  2. Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination
  3. James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. If it results in 2 living children, it will be Live 2.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G2P2: Incorrect because the woman has had only one previous pregnancy that reached viability, not two.

 

Option B. G3P2: Incorrect because this implies she has had three pregnancies and two have reached viability, which is not the case.

 

Option D. G3P1: Incorrect because this implies three pregnancies, but she is currently in her second pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A twin pregnancy that has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1, not Para 2. If it results in two living children, it will be Live 2.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling to exert its functions.

 

Insulin receptor is a tetramer, formed by four glycoprotein subunits (two α-subunits and two β-subunits). The α-subunits protrude out of the cell and the β-subunits protrude inside the cell. The α and β subunits are linked to each other by disulfide bonds. Intracellular surfaces of α-subunits have the enzyme activity – protein kinase (tyrosine kinase) activity.

 

When insulin binds with α-subunits of the receptor protein, the tyrosine kinase at the β-subunit (that protrudes into the cell) is activated by means of autophosphorylation.

 

Activated tyrosine kinase acts on many intracellular enzymes by phosphorylating or dephosphorylating them so that some of the enzymes are activated while others are inactivated

 

Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes

 

  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • hormones acting via cytokine receptor - Prolactin, Growth hormone

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. TSH acts through a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), not a receptor tyrosine kinase. It stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones by activating the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway.

 

Option C. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): Incorrect. TRH also utilizes G protein-coupled receptors and primarily influences the pituitary gland to release TSH, using intracellular signaling mechanisms involving phospholipase C.

 

Option D. MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. MSH binds to melanocortin receptors, which are GPCRs, and is involved in a variety of functions including skin pigmentation and appetite regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin uniquely uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling among the options listed, activating complex pathways that are essential for regulating glucose metabolism and other metabolic processes in the body.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

When a person is in the supine position (lying on their back), aspirated material is most likely to enter the superior basel segment of the right lower lobe (upper part of the right inferior lobe). The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus. This makes the right side more susceptible to aspiration in general. And in the supine position, gravity makes the superior basel segment of the lower lobes (particularly on the right side) the most dependent and thus the most likely site for aspiration.

 

Aspiration of gastric contents can cause chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia, which can affect different parts of the lung depending on the patient's position during aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: The lingula is a segment of the left upper lobe of the lung. It corresponds anatomically to the right middle lobe but on the left side. Due to the angulation of the main bronchi, it's less common for aspirated contents to travel into the left main bronchus when compared to the right. Thus, while it's possible for aspirated material to reach the lingula, especially in certain positions or conditions, it's not the most common site of aspiration.

 

Option C. Right superior lobe: This lobe isn't the primary location for aspiration in the supine position. However, if someone were to aspirate while standing or sitting upright, aspirated material might be more likely to enter the apical (uppermost) segments of the right upper lobe.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: The right middle lobe, particularly its bronchus, is more susceptible to aspiration when an individual is in the lateral decubitus position (lying on their side). The lateral segment of the right middle lobe becomes the most dependent segment in this position. But again, in the supine position, the right middle lobe isn't the primary site of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient is in a supine position and aspirates, superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites.

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:
